div.div: Parent, Guardians, Coaches, and Student/Athletes, First off, I hope everyone is doing well, and your families are safe and healthy. My thoughts are with all of you every day during these trying times for all of us. Late last week, Governor Evers extended the "Safer at Home" order until May 26 and has closed school for the remainder of the 2019-2020 academic year, which is through June 30. On Tuesday, the WIAA officially cancelled the Spring Sports Season and the Spring WIAA State Tournament events. The WIAA sent out clarity as to summer guidelines. Below are parts of the news release from the WIAA. "The WIAA Board voted to extend the unrestricted summertime coaching contact opportunities for spring sports only. This action will permit school teams that include the current year's seniors to assemble and conduct practices and competitions for up to 30 days after June 30, provided restrictions on assembling in groups are removed, until the start of a student-athlete's fall sports season. The cancellation of all extracurricular activities prohibits all school or coach involvement with training, practices, scrimmages and contests until, at the earliest July 1, unless restrictions are removed prior to that time. Therefore, coaches may not bring students together or encourage students to assemble for extracurricular purposes, which includes competitions, practices and all instructional and training until the restrictions on assembling in groups are removed. All coaches are encouraged to continue to connect with their student-athletes with virtual organizational meetings to provide support for athletes. Spring sports coaches may continue to provide individual virtual instruction for student-athletes with training, conditioning and skill development until the end of the respective spring sports season. Fall and winter sports coaches' contact may begin July 1–provided restrictions on assembling in groups are removed." I could not be more heartbroken for our student-athletes, especially our Seniors. The time, effort, and dedication that have been given which has allowed our student-athletes to have a great experience in their given sport by all stakeholders is nothing short of amazing and appreciated. To our Seniors, Thank you! Be proud of your accomplishments during your time in Athletics at Lancaster High School. Your contributions have been much appreciated. Best of luck to you as you move forward, as handling this difficult situation will prepare you to handle anything that comes your way! To our Underclassmen, continue to work individually as a student and as an athlete. We will come out of this challenging situation stronger. Continue to support your teammates, to individually work on athletic skills and strength/conditioning. Your coaches and myself are here for you. Please let us know if there is anything we can do to help... In closing, our School District, Athletic Department, Student/Athletes, Coaches, Parents, and Community, let's support each other, stay strong, and stay positive! Thank you, and Go Flying Arrows! Coach Hoch

span.a: You are currently on this page - Covid-19 Updates

td.h2: Protecting Our Students and Community from Coronavirus

td.h3: Lancaster Community Schools closed until further notice
td.p: Gov. Tony Evers on March 13, 2020 ordered the closure of all K-12 Wisconsin schools, public and private, from Wednesday, March 18 to April 5, as part of the state's efforts to respond to and contain the spread of COVID-19 in Wisconsin. The announcement affects almost 855,000 students in more than 400 districts across the state - and adds Wisconsin to a growing list of states to close schools.

“Closing our schools is not a decision I made lightly, but keeping our kids, our educators, our families, and our communities safe is a top priority as we continue our work to respond to and prevent further spread of COVID-19 in Wisconsin,” Evers said. “Kids and families across Wisconsin often depend on our schools to access food and care. We are going to continue working to do everything we can to ensure kids and families have the resources and support they need while schools are closed.”

Lancaster Community Schools will be closed from March 16 until further notice. All after-school activities, including extra-curricular practices, are canceled while school is closed. This also includes any non-school activities held on school grounds.
Gov. Evers enacted a Safer At Home Order on March 24, which continues until April 24. The Order continues the closure of all K-12 Wisconsin schools, public and private, that began last month.
For those families in the Snack Pack for Backpacks program, our staff will be contacting you soon to set up a pick up or delivery (if needed) time.

Grab and go breakfast and lunch will be available for pick up at each school for any child (up to and including age 18) in the Lancaster Community School District. During the pick up times you will receive your breakfast and lunch for that day. Please only one visit per day for your meals.

Lancaster Community Schools will begin delivery of the Grab and Go meals on rural bus routes beginning Wednesday, March 25. In light of Gov. Evers’ Safer at Home order beginning Tuesday, March 24, drop offs will not be made in the City of Lancaster (Baus Park, Schreiner Memorial Library and the swimming pool).

Meals will be available for pick up at Lancaster Middle/High School from 6:30 a.m. until 9:30 a.m. each Monday and Wednesday. Please practice social distancing while picking up meals at the middle/high school. Please wait until those ahead of you in line are a safe distance away before you proceed to pick up. Safety is our number one priority.

Buses will depart the schools at approximately 7 a.m. and all food will be delivered by 9 a.m. Please practice social distancing and pick up your food after the bus driver has left your residence. Thank you very much for your patience and understanding as we work through this unprecedented time together.

Our Food Service department would like to advise that the breakfast or lunch meals should be refrigerated if not being consumed immediately. Items included in the meals could spoil as a result of not being stored properly. All protein items included in the meals are precooked and safe to eat without any further cooking. These meals are not 100 percent allergy free please take note of items before consumption. Please discard any refrigerated leftovers within three days
If you have any questions, please contact Laurie Simmons, Director of Food Service, at (608) 723-2173 (ext. 326).

Winskill Elementary School and Lancaster Middle/High School will continue to educate all students during the state-mandated closure of our school buildings. Our educational plan will be a blend of paper materials and online virtual education.

In light of Gov. Tony Evers' Safer At Home Order issued on March 24 and continuing until April 24, Winskill Elementary School and Lancaster Middle/High School revised their educational plans on April 1.

You may read Winskill Elementary School's educational plan here. Please find a Spanish language version of Winskill Elementary's educational plan here. Find details of Winskill's Zoom Classroom Sessions here.
You may read Lancaster Middle/High School's educational plan here. Please find a Spanish language version of the Middle/High School educational plan here.

li.p: Please contact TDS or Spectrum Charter if you are in need of WiFi/Hotspots.
Spectrum: To enroll in the program, call 1-844-488-8395. Installation fees will be waived for new student households.

TDS: (TDS will offer free internet for low-income families and college students. To verify eligibility for this offer, residents will be asked to provide documentation from qualifying programs. For more information, call 1-888-287-8156.

img.alt: Symptoms of Coronavirus - fever, cough and shortness of breath

td.div: The safety of our students and staff is our top priority. When school resumes, please watch for the following symptoms. Keep students home from school and contact their physician to ask to be tested for Coronavirus if they have these symptoms:
td.p: Please contact your child's school to report the absence and symptoms. Learn more about the symptoms and treatment of Coronavirus at the Center for Disease Control (CDC) website. Those at highest risk for Coronavirus complications are older adults and individuals with compromised immune systems or heart, lung and kidney disease. See how Coronavirus is spread. It can take two to 14 days for a person to develop symptoms after initial exposure to the virus; the average is about five days.

p.strong: We have no known cases of COVID-19 among students or staff in Lancaster Community Schools.

td.p: We continue to closely monitor the situation with our School Nurses and Grant County Health Departments, as well as review updates from the Wisconsin Department of Health Services, Department of Public Instruction and the CDC. Here is the latest information on confirmed cases in Wisconsin. Another 37 WI residents returned March 16 from a cruise where they may have been exposed and will be self-quarantined for 14 days.

img.alt: How to Prevent the Spread of Germs

h3.b: What You Can Do and Our Cleaning Measures

td.p: Lancaster Community Schools has a routine cleaning regimen in place to help reduce the spread of germs and communicable disease. In addition to our regular cleaning and disinfection, we are increasing the cleaning of high-touch areas and hard and soft surface items throughout the day. We will follow all guidelines of the CDC and our local and state health departments.
td.div: We all play a role in helping reduce the spread of communicable disease. We are asking our students, staff and families to practice regular preventive actions (see flyer in English, Spanish, Hmong and Mandarin Chinese) including:

ul.li: Wash your hands regularly, for 20 seconds, using soap and hot water. Make sure to wash your fingertips. This is especially important after using the restroom, coughing or sneezing into your hands, and before preparing or consuming food.
Avoid coughing or sneezing into your hands or in the air. Always try to cough or sneeze into a tissue, and then throw the tissue away. If you don’t have a tissue, cough/sneeze into your arm.
As much as you can, avoid touching your eyes, mouth and nose.

If children are feeling sick, please keep them home from school. Families should have a plan in place for keeping your child home, picking up your child if they are sent home sick, and if schools are closed.
